advert.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT, SEPTEMBER 1985</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Doctors, it gonna cure your work" <br><br> "ITT 3030, the absolute intelligence"</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> PROF80 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote>French advert from Pentasonic stores chain.</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> APPLE TEMPTATION...</strong></font><br><blockquote>Franklin dealer advert (1983)</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. AD. (1983) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Our all-in-one BMC IF-800 computer is easier for dealers to sell, customers to buy and OEM to use in their systems...<br> ... You can upgrade to a 16 bit CPU which offers IBM PC compatible MS-DOS and CP/M-86...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> RUSSIAN ADVERT - PAGE 2</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to Taras Ponomarev for this advert</p></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977) #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This advert (May 1977) introduced the <b>System 16</b>, same as assembled System 7 with 16 Kb of RAM. ($1995)</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (SEPT. 1983)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> ONTEL ADVERT #2</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> 1977 ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT </strong></font><br><blockquote>advert said<br><br><font color="#666666"> ...If you want a computer that won't be obsolete in a few years, buy an MSX.<br> If you want one of the best-selling MSX computers in Japan, buy a Toshiba HX10.</font></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> COMPUSTAR AD #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Compustar standard features in 1983:<br> - 350 KB / 750 KB / 1.5 MB workstation disk capacities<br> - 10 to 144 MB storage options<br><br> Advert said:<br><br><font color="#666666"> Compustar is built and backed by the company that's been in the microcomputer business as long as microcomputers have been in business. Would you trust your business to anything less?</font> </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> OHIO BROCHURE</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> AN ADVERTISING</strong></font><br><blockquote>I couldn't resist putting this photo here. The girl looks very happy, the ad said "The new System III can be provided with walnut floor cabinet".</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> US ADVERT</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> GERMAN BROCHURE #1</strong></font><br><blockquote><p class="petitgris">Thanks to <b>Volken</b></p></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT (1982)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT #2 (JUNE 1985)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> NORTHSTAR CARDS</strong></font><br><blockquote>Northstar also designed cards for S100 Bus. These cards were used in the Horizon and were also available separately for competing systems.<br> Cards on the photo are:<br> - 16 KB RAM board ($459 assembled)<br> - Micro Disk System (card & interface) to connect Shugart FDD ($799)<br> - Z80A processor board ($259 without EPROM option, $330 with)<br> - Hardware floating point card ($359). </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FIRST AD. </strong></font><br><blockquote>The red part shows all the IBM-PC software boxes the VP could run.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> U.S. ADVERT (1977) #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>An advert dédicated to Polymorphic BASIC language features and to a new version of the system named System 0.<br><br> The <b>System 0</b> was intended for the users who already have a S-100 Bus based system and wanted to transform it into a Poly 88 system. It consisted of the central processor card with ROM monitor, the video card and the cassette interface, all in kit form. Price: $525 </blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD #1 (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>"Electron, the personal micro which has talents of a pro"...</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH AD (JAN. 1980)</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH ADVERT. (1984)</strong></font><br><blockquote>This is nearly a stupid scan ! <br><br> The young boy says : ''In 1984, my father bought me a MO-5" <br> And on his desk is a 1998 calendar... <br><br> They meant that if you bought the MO-5 then (the advert is from 1984), you would be rich and clever 14 years later (in 1998). Ha ha ha !! <br><br> It's funny to see how they tried to represent an office and a town of 1998. I really love this one ! </blockquote>

computer.description:
Shelton Instruments were the people behind the original design of the Nascom 1. They were based in London.
Sig-Net was a totally new concept, whereby a series of boards - processor, interface, memory, etc. - were interconnected by flexible wires.
Each board had its own power supply and many variations of computer could be evolved from the basic system components.
The Sig-Net 200 series computer had a number of these modules housed in an enclosure that can have two integral floppy disc drives. The system came with 64 KB of RAM and up to 4 KB of ROM. There were two RS232 interfaces and a 4-channel real-time clock.A hard disk controller could be connected on-board.
The system was indefinitely expandable, even to a multi-processor system, using Sig-Net modules. CP/M 2.2 operating system came with the computer allowing the vast CP/M library of software to be used.
computer.graphics: A graphic card was available - Features unknown
computer.keyboard: Depending on the video terminal used
computer.media: 1 to 4 200, 400 or 800 KB 5'' floppy disc drives
computer.name: Sig-Net
computer.peripherals: Optional 7 MB hard disk (?3300 + ?600 for the controller)
computer.ports: 2 x Serial RS232, 1 x Parallel Centronics
computer.power: Built-in power supply unit + one power supply per card
